main event: A civilian in Boise, Idaho, observed a stationary bright and silvery halo circle object clinging to a cloud for a few minutes in 1947.
interesting points: The object was observed to be 10 miles away from the observer at an altitude of 3,000 feet.
It was described as a round disc with a black and silver color, resembling a dinner saucer.
Local weather reports indicated a clear sky, contradicting the observation that the object seemed to be clinging to a high cloud.
The investigator suggested that the observed object was a sunlit lenticularis cloud effect, based on the position of the sun and his own observations of similar effects.

The document discusses evaluations by Dr. Hynek based on probabilities and explanations, categorizing incidents into astronomical and non-astronomical events with varying levels of evidence and explanations.
sighted object: stationary bright and silvery halo circle object
